Award.AwardTitle: Optical Characterization of Intrinsic Properties and Fabric of Coarse-Grained Soils

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to bring intrinsic soil properties including particle shape, angularity and surface roughness as well as soil fabric into wider common practice and research through development of optical methods for rapidly quantifying them at no extra time or cost than required to develop grain size distributions. To accomplish this, a sediment imaging (Sedimaging) system will be used for particles smaller than 2 mm and a translucent segregation table (TST) will be used for the coarser fraction. Both systems rapidly sort a statistically representative soil specimen prior to image capture. Most importantly, although the particles are sorted, they need not be separated from contact with each other. This allows for a large number of particles to be rapidly evaluated. Furthermore, because of the recent introduction of high resolution cameras approaching 40 MPix, only one high resolution photograph is needed in each test. The major research tasks include: development of advanced Sedimaging and TST systems; segmentation of particles from images of 3D assemblies and selection of segmented particles for shape analysis; quantification of particle shape of segmented particles; comparison of particle Roundness and Sphericity obtained from Sedimaging and TST images with traditionally obtained (ex-situ) measures; determination of typical shape distributions as a function of particle size within specimens; establishing minimum particle size for which shape descriptors should be determined; evaluation of surface roughness by corner detection methods; development of a wavelet-based index for soil fabric potential; performance of laboratory tests for confirmation of previous findings on particle shape and fabric effects; and extension of methods to images collected in-situ by the vision cone penetrometer.

Broader impacts will be addressed on three distinct fronts. First, the Sedimaging and TST tests will become regular and distinct laboratory exercises in the undergraduate Introductory Geotechnical Engineering course at the University of Michigan. This will demonstrate that research findings and developments do transfer into engineering practice. Secondly, working with the University of Michigan Ergonomics Research Center and three local sand and aggregate producers, the geotechnical laboratory work environment will be evaluated with emphasis on improvements created by the Sedimaging and TST systems that relieve workers from the tedium of particle size and aspect ratio testing. Finally, the impediments to technology transfer (from research to practice) in geotechnical and geoenvironmental engineering will be investigated and documented by geotechnical specialty area (i.e soil improvement, deep foundations, retaining structures, etc.).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design, construction and maintenance of safe and economic infrastructure components including buildings, dams, levees, highways, tunnels, bridges, power plants, landfills and soil retaining walls requires accurate characterization of the earth materials with which the infrastructure components will interact to insure their integrity under loading and resilience in the face of natural and manmade hazards.  The critical engineering properties of soils may be grouped into two categories: state properties such as density and in-situ stresses and intrinsic properties which do not change when a soil is removed from its geologic setting.  The intrinsic category includes soil particle size and shape distributions. These particle level intrinsic properties are major factors controlling the macroscopic strength, compressibility, packing efficiency, and hydraulic conductivity of soils. 

This research project developed laboratory and field testing systems that prepare soils for digital image capture. The University of Michigan Geotechnical Image Analysis Laboratory featuring these systems is shown in Figure 1.  The captured images are analyzed for their particle size and shape distributions.  Preparation of soil specimens containing sands smaller than 2 millimeters utilizes rapid sorting of the particles by a 2-meter tall water-filled sedimentation column (see Fig. 1) prior to image capture. The system is referred to as Sedimaging.  The image analysis utilizes advanced wavelet mathematics to convert gray-scale image textures in thousands of small square analysis areas containing approximately 25 to several hundred particles each to develop complete particle size distributions (PSDs).  The Sedimaging test image analysis is calibrated so that it yields a particle size distribution according to the traditional soil particle size as defined by sieve openings. The Sedimaging test is more rapid, less expensive, uses less water and consumes less energy than sieving.  It also requires much less maintenance and improves safety in the work environment. Both stationary laboratory and low-cost field-portable versions of Sedimaging were developed and utilized in this research.  

For coarser sands and gravels, a 1 m x 1 m Translucent Sorting Table (TST) was developed.  It too is shown in Fig. 1. Images are captured of particles on the back-lit TST table using two cameras. Stereophotography algorithms were developed for characterizing the three-dimensional size and shape of every particle in a soil specimen.  A table-top version of the stereophotography is shown in Figure 1.

A particle?s shape is quantified by its Sphericity (S) and Roundness (R).  Various definitions have been proposed for each. The simplest and arguably most common definition of S is the ratio of smaller to larger particle dimension when the particle is viewed in its largest area projection. In the geosciences and geotechnical engineering R is defined as the ratio of the average of radii of circles fitted to the corners of a particle to the radius of the largest circle inscribed within the particle.  Thus, for a perfect circle, both R and S are 1.0.  Computational geometry codes were developed to determine R and S from images of particle projections. This has eliminated the need for manual fitting of circles to corners and the use of previously developed charts for visual estimation of R and S. Soils of various particle shapes (R & S), gradations and geologic origins were laboratory tested for their strengths, compressibilities and packing indices to develop functional relationships between these macroscopic properties of soils and their intrinsic properties.

The computational geometry algorithm that was developed for determining R was then utilized to help computer-generate particles for numerical distinct element modeling (DEM) of particle assemblies undergoing simulated loading and deformation.  A library containing over 100,000 particles of various S and R pairs was created.  A soil with any desired R and S distribution can now be recreated for computer simulation using particles from the library.  A specific particle gradation can also be modeled by individually upsizing or downsizing the library particles. 

When particles of low Sphericity are deposited in a fluvial environment, they settle with their longer axes in the horizontal plane.  The resulting cross-anisotropic fabric means that the soils macroscopic mechanical and hydrologic behavior will be directionally-dependent. The Sedimaging test simulates the fluvial depositional environment. Therefore, methods were developed using the aforementioned wavelet mathematics to quantify the orientation and degree of soil anisotropy from images of deposited soils.

Lastly, procedures and lessons learned in analysis of laboratory soil images are being adopted towards analysis of images collected in-situ with a newly developed Vision Cone Penetrometer (VisCPT). The VisCPT characterizes soil stratigraphy optically and continuously with depth without the need for soil sampling and laboratory testing.  A third generation of the VisCPT is being developed in collaboration with ConeTec, a leading private sector developer of in-situ soil testing systems.
